conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the given p-V diagram of an ideal gas undergoing two adiabatic and two isochoric processes.
The diagram shows the pressure (P) versus volume (V) for two cycles: one adiabatic process from a to c and another adiabatic process from a to d.
In an adiabatic process, no heat is exchanged with the surroundings, so the internal energy of the gas remains constant.
For the adiabatic process from a to c, since it is an isothermal process, the internal energy U at state a is equal to the internal energy at state c.
For the adiabatic process from a to d, since it is an isothermal process, the internal energy U at state a is equal to the internal energy at state d.

Since the internal energy at state a is equal to the internal energy at state c and the internal energy at state a is equal to the internal energy at state d, the internal energy at state a is the same for both adiabatic processes.
Compare the internal energies at state a and state c. Since both states have the same internal energy, the internal energy at state a is equal to the internal energy at state c.
Conclude that the internal energy at state a is equal to the internal energy at state c.
The internal energy at state a is equal to the internal energy at state c.
